awd_titl_txt: Development of New Techniques: Sustaining and sharpening amino acid geochronology
awd_abstract_narration:
Determining the ages of geological materials (geochronology) is fundamental to understanding Earth's history. Amino acid racemization (AAR) geochronology is a dating method applicable to a wide range of fossils types, depositional environments, and time scales. It enables research in a broad range of geoscience topics such as archeology, historical ecology, paleontology, tectonic geomorphology, paleoceanography, glacial geology, and others. This award will support scientific infrastructure by sustaining the laboratory for AAR geochronology at Northern Arizona University. 

This project will sharpen one of the most outstanding untapped applications of AAR geochronology: as a dating method for marine sediment cores using foraminifera. Various procedures will be tested to reduce analytical variability, a major source of error for AAR geochronology when applied to foraminifera. Several widely occurring foraminifera taxa will be subjected to chemical pre-treatments to isolate a fraction of amino acids that is less prone to post-depositional environmental influences. Once optimized, the treatment will be applied to samples from a network of stratigraphic reference horizons from well-dated deep-sea cores. The data will be used to evaluate the reproducibility of AAR geochronology among the sites and to calibrate the rate of racemization for several reference species. Samples from other sites will be used to quantify the possible influence of different geothermal gradients on the extent of racemization in foraminifera. Recently developed data-analytical approaches will be employed to model the time-dependent rate of racemization and to characterize age uncertainties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Determining the ages of geological materials (geochronology) is fundamental to understanding Earth’s history. Different geochronological techniques are needed to solve different research questions, depending on the materials available and their ages. Amino acid racemization (AAR) geochronology is a dating method applicable to a wide range of fossil types, depositional environments, and time scales ranging from hundreds to hundreds-of-thousands of years. It enables research into a broad range of Earth science topics such as historical ecology, paleontology, tectonic geomorphology, paleoceanography, glacial geology, and others. Most of the studies supported by this award have societal relevance. For instance, they helped to understand human impacts on marine and lacustrine ecological systems, the impact of global warming on sea level, and changes in the polar ice caps under changing climate.

Despite its broad utility, during the last 30 years, the number of AAR geochronology laboratories in North America has dwindled from 16 to 1. This award supported scientific infrastructure by sustaining a laboratory for AAR geochronology. It enabled the full-time operation of the Amino Acid Geochronology Laboratory (AAGL) at Northern Arizona University (NAU) by helping to support the laboratory’s PhD-level manager, which is key to its productivity and to the continuity of its results, and to continuing its tradition of training users, offering experimental analyses for technique improvements, and facilitating the archival of AAR geochronology data. This award also supported multiple graduate students through assistantships and training in AAR geochronology. Two PhD students visited the lab a week or two of hands-on training. One recent graduate is seeking a postdoctoral position to expand their expertise in the technique, and possibly help to sustain AAR geochronology into the future.

In addition to supporting the operations of the AAGL, this award enabled the lab to expand its analytical capacity for dating carbonate fossils by dovetailing with the new radiocarbon lab at NAU. The two techniques are complementary: While radiocarbon provides a precise age for fossils, it is applicable only to those that are younger than around 30,000 years. While AAR geochronology is less precise, it can be applied to much older materials. This award was used to purchase a Carbonate Handling System (CHS) for NAU’s accelerator mass spectrometer (MICADAS). The CHS automatically dissolves the biomineral and injects the evolved CO2 gas directly into the MICADAS for rapid measurement of its radiocarbon content. This project tested the CHS. The results show that it is an efficient alternative to other radiocarbon dating procedures, especially for small samples or when the highest precision results are not required.

This project supported a large number of Earth scientists who used AAR and radiocarbon geochronology for a wide variety of research projects. During the four-year funding period (7/1/19 to 6/30/23), the AAGL reported results for 5544 AAR analyses and 2848 radiocarbon samples. The samples were submitted by at least 47 different Earth scientists, including 17 graduate students and 5 postdoctoral researchers. During the four-year period, results from the AAGL were published in at least 39 peer-reviewed articles (the PI was co-author on 18 of these), 1 book chapter, 3 datasets, and 14 abstracts for professional meetings. Multiple other articles are in review. During the funding period, the AAGL provided training in AAR procedures and interpretation of geochronological data for 7 completed graduate theses. The award funded 2 graduate assistantships and 4 undergraduate laboratory assistants at NAU.

This project sharpened one its most outstanding untapped applications of AAR geochronology: as a dating method for marine sediment cores using foraminifera. This project focused on existing cores from both polar regions where cryosphere changes can lead to pronounced shifts in sedimentation rate that complicate the interpretation of the stratigraphic sequences. Improved geochronology in this setting is important for understanding sea ice and other oceanographic changes, and ice-sheet dynamics over glacial-interglacial cycles to better understand how they relate to changing climate. Various procedures were tested to reduce analytical variability, a major source of uncertainty for AAR geochronology when applied to foraminifera. Widely occurring foraminifera taxa were subjected to chemical pre-treatments to test whether they reduced the intra-sample variability, but the outcome produced only minor improvement, if any. This project also analyzed foraminifera from a network of stratigraphic reference horizons from well-dated deep-sea cores. The data were used to calibrate the rate of racemization for several foraminifera species. The new age equations are now being applied to marine cores in need of improved chronological control, especially in the Arctic Ocean, arguably the least well known of the world’s oceans.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.
